title: Working with Fields
description: Learn to use fields effectively—the key to precise, powerful searches. Master field selection, the fields command, and the table command.
objectives: Understand the difference between default and extracted fields
Use the field sidebar to explore available fields
Select specific fields with the fields command
Create clean output tables with the table command

sections.title: Why Fields Matter
sections.body:
Raw log events are just text. Fields turn that text into structured, searchable data.

Consider this raw event:

Jan 15 10:23:45 server01 sshd[12345]: Accepted password for admin from 192.168.1.50 port 52431

As text, you can search for "admin" or "192.168.1.50", but you can't easily:

  • Find all events from IP 192.168.1.50 without matching other numbers
  • Count logins per user
  • Compare login patterns across time

With fields extracted:

FieldValue
useradmin
src_ip192.168.1.50
src_port52431
actionAccepted
hostserver01

Now you can write precise searches and aggregate data meaningfully.

sections.title: Finding Available Fields
sections.body:
The field sidebar (left side of results) shows all fields Splunk found in your results.

Field Categories

  • Selected Fields: Fields shown in your results view (host, source, sourcetype by default)
  • Interesting Fields: Fields present in at least 20% of your events

Exploring a Field

Click any field name to see:

  • Top 10 values: Most common values
  • Count: How many events have each value
  • %: Percentage of events with that value

All Fields

Click All Fields at the bottom to see every extracted field, including:

  • Fields that appear in fewer than 20% of events
  • Internal fields (starting with underscore)

sections.explanation: After running this search, use the field sidebar to explore available fields like component, log_level, and message.

sections.title: The fields Command
sections.body:
The fields command controls which fields are available in your search results.

Keeping Only Specific Fields

example.spl:
index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd
| fields _time, host, log_level, message

sections.explanation:
This removes all fields except _time, host, log_level, and message. Benefits:

  • Cleaner results
  • Faster processing (less data to handle)
  • Focus on what matters

Removing Specific Fields
sections.explanation2: The minus sign removes fields. Useful when you want most fields but need to hide a few.

sections.title: The table Command
sections.body: The table command creates a clean table with just the fields you specify.

example.spl:
index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd log_level=ERROR
| table _time, host, component, message

sections.explanation:
table displays results as a clean table with columns for each field. Key points:

  • Fields appear in the order you list them
  • Only events with at least one of the fields appear
  • Results show in the Statistics tab

fields vs table

CommandPurposeOutput
fieldsControl which fields exist in the pipelineStill in Events tab
tableCreate formatted tabular outputSwitches to Statistics tab

Use fields mid-search to slim down data; use table at the end to format output.

sections.title: Renaming Fields
sections.body: The rename command gives fields more readable names.

example.spl:
index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd log_level=ERROR
| table _time, host, component, message
| rename _time as "Time", host as "Server", component as "Component", message as "Error Message"

sections.explanation:
This creates a table with cleaner column headers. Useful for:

  • Reports that others will read
  • Dashboard panels
  • Exports to CSV

Note: Use quotes around names with spaces.

sections.title: Default Fields
sections.body:
Every event has these default fields automatically:

FieldDescriptionExample
_timeEvent timestamp (epoch)1705320225
_rawOriginal event textThe full log line
hostSource systemserver01
sourceFile or input path/var/log/auth.log
sourcetypeData format typelinux_secure
indexWhich index stores thislinux

These are always available without configuration.

sections.title: Internal Fields
sections.body:
Fields starting with underscore (_) are internal Splunk fields.

FieldDescription
_timeEvent timestamp
_rawOriginal event text
_indextimeWhen Splunk indexed the event
_bktBucket (storage location)
_serialEvent sequence number

The two you'll use most are _time (always include in tables) and _raw (the original event).

sections.title: Practical Examples
sections.body:
Example 1: Simple Event Listing

List errors with key fields:

example.spl:
index=_internal log_level=ERROR
| table _time, host, sourcetype, message
| head 20

sections.explanation2: The top command shows the most common values for a field—great for exploration.

example3.spl:
index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd
| fields _time, host, log_level, component, message
| search log_level=ERROR
| table _time, host, component, message

sections.explanation3: Adding fields early in your search reduces the data Splunk processes, making subsequent commands faster.

sections.title: Practice Exercises
sections.body:
Try these exercises to practice working with fields.

Exercise 1: Basic Table

Create a table showing time, host, and log_level from _internal:

example.spl:
index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd
| table _time, host, log_level
| head 50

exercises.title: Exercise 2: Rename Fields
exercises.prompt: Create the same table but rename log_level to 'Severity'
exercises.solution:
index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd
| table _time, host, log_level
| rename log_level as Severity
| head 50

exercises.prompt: Run a search and remove the _raw field to see just extracted fields

exercises.prompt: Find the top 10 components in splunkd logs

content.summary:
Key Takeaways

  • Fields turn unstructured logs into searchable, analyzable data
  • Use the field sidebar to discover available fields
  • fields controls which fields exist in your search pipeline
  • table creates clean tabular output from your results
  • rename gives fields more readable names
  • Default fields (_time, host, source, etc.) are always available
  • Always include _time in tables to show when events occurred
